ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Multivariable calculus, managing a heavy courseload

I gained a strong understanding of concepts in multivariable calculus and was able to further refine my understanding of calculus I learned in high school. This course was very intense with the problem sets, so I was also able to learn how to balance that workload over the week as a first year student.
I know how to use random formulas of which I have no understanding.
green's theorem, stokes theorem, partial derivatives, line integrals, surface integrals, vector line integrals, divergence theorem, fundamental theorem of line integrals
Knowledge of multivariable calculus.

Basic multivariable calculus, no more and no less. The final cumulative was harder than the two midterms, but as long as you watch the videos on Canvas and understand the general principles, the class is not too much to handle.
Multivariable Calc! I have a good sense of 3D geometry and vector equations.
I learned how to apply new concepts in depth.
I learned how to think in 3D and extend my knowledge 1D and 2D calculus.
I learned multivariable and vector calculus, and improved my general problem-solving skills.
I learned multivariable calculus quite well, and became much more interested in math.
Knowledge of calculus that will be more useful for physics than for anything else in mathematics (which linear algebra is more involved in, I think).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is highly self-directed, and it requires a lot of discipline and organization to not fall behind. I personally did not enjoy how the teaching style was flipped classroom, because I think there is value to learning concepts together with a group and having someone to ask questions to as you're learning the content.

I feel like since this was just like a basic class that is useful for a lot of classes, it felt more like a pre-req where the strengths lied in the concepts I learned. Also, the feedback we received on our exams and problem sets were very comprehensive, so it was very easy to learn from our mistakes and apply those changes to our future assignments/exams. The weakness of this course was that it was taught by first-year grad students, so not only were we learning this concept for the first time, the grad students were teaching it for the first time, so it was really hard to learn.

The structure (learning the material before class and then relearning it in class) seems kind of silly. There is no explanation of the motivation for anything; you're just given a bunch of formulas. If you just want to learn the techniques of multivariable calculus, this course is ok, but it makes no effort to do anything beyond that (and you'll be learning those techniques on your own from the videos).

The course itself has very few strengths and many weaknesses. Perhaps the only strength is that the teaching fellows are not needed to learn the course  the entirety of the course could essentially be learned through the textbook and psets. The teaching fellows are perhaps the biggest weakness of the course - varying greatly in quality (usually ending up on the lower end of the quality spectrum) and often helping very little in engagement or understanding.
more guided practice problems could have helped
The problem sets are considerably harder than the tests and there needs to be more office and peer tutor hours.

The strength is that it covers the basics of multivariable calculus. It teaches what it is suppose to teach. A huge weakness is that graduate students are instructors, and some are not as experienced nor motivated. My instructor was not very engaging, and many students stopped attending lectures. I found the motivation very low, and thus did not enjoy the learning. I wish I had a more motivating class environment.
This class does not facilitate student learning in any way whatsoever.

Strengths: There are a lot of resources to help you learn the material.
Weaknesses: The pre-class quizzes did not help with anything. I don't think there was a point in doing them.

The accessibility of resources to help with your understanding outside of class for this course is incredibly strong, between office hours and exceptional peer tutors. They also provide so many online resources such as practice problems through Ximena and pre-class videos which help when reveiwing the material. However, this course was not great at maintaining student engagement -- for reference, my 25 person class had a solid 5-person average attendance per class. The majority of classes, at least in my section, covered theory, while the PSets and the tests mainly covered computational problems. You could easily have simply taught yourself the material from the textbook and by going to peer tutoring sessions where the computational material was covered better (albeit about 20 people in my class did). I found myself learning the most from the problem sets and the textbook rather than in class itself.

Strengths:
- Well-organized and good course in multivariable calculus (reasonable content and problem sets)
- A lot of support for learning from peers and tutors
Weaknesses:
- A lot of variance in teaching quality between sections
- Seems to be less focus upon proofs and explanations of why rather than use of theorems
How to improve:
- Understand that some instructors are good at learning math but not necessarily teaching it, so maybe emphasize teaching a bit more as well
- Extend more beyond just using theorems, add more optional proofs (e.g. point to parts in the textbook where the proofs are done)

Sri is not a good teacher. He is slow and makes mistakes when working out problems on the board. His explanations are roundabout. Students would benefit from having more experienced grad students teach, if not full professors (which is, after all, what most of them are actually paying for).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend the course if you're interested in STEM and Math, but if not an easier course could be better

I would just because it could be crucial for a lot of STEM courses offered at Yale. Even if those STEM courses don't require the concepts, the problem solving and critical thinking ensures that students are actually applying concepts they understand rather than plugging and chugging.

I would only recommend this course to someone who needs it as a prerequisite. Otherwise, I don't think it's at all interesting or intellectually satisfying, although the difficulty is very reasonable. I know multiple people who wanted to be math majors until they took this course.
yes, to students interested in mathematics
Yes, but you will have to put a lot of time into it to do well.
I think if you are in any kind of science or engineering take ENAS 151
If this is not necessary for your major, then I would not recommend it.
Yes, if it is required for their major. I think it's a really useful class, but there is no point in taking it if you aren't considering pursuing anything STEM related.
If you need Math 120 or a math for your major, then yes. Otherwise, if you just need a QR credit, then I would suggest considering another class that would be more engaging.
Yes, I think that this course was very thorough and I learned a lot.

I would recommend this as a good calculus course. But if you're someone more into math itself (or majors that require more intensive math), this course may be easier and shallower than what you might be looking for because of its lack in explanations and proofs.
No. Very poor teacher. The abysmal quality of this course section should be a cause of shame for the mathematics department.
